div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,425] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definaitely engaged beforehand: Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monda.A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving inLondon at the very convenient hour of 4.56.p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fair is £22.9.11 Port Said to London vis Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leaves Suez for Aden and Bombay every WEdnesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Our predictions of a fl e day yesterday were falsifled. The morning opened bright and clear but the conditions soon changed, Some rain fell accompanied by hall during the day, and at 9 p.m. there was an unusually heavy downpour of hail which was of ahort duration. This morning opens cool, but raw and cloudy, with a light breeze from the W. and a rising barometer.

THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: LANCASHIRE COTTON BOOM
div.p: It is so inspiriting to bear of any British manufacturing industry in a highly prosperous condition despite hostile foreign tariffs that patriotism shrinks from casting doubt on the continuance of the phenomenal boom in English cotton goods. This happy change from the long period when so many Lancashire mills were either closed or only running half-time began eighteen months ago, the American "corner" in the raw material haring utterly collapsed for the time being. In itself, this sodden expansion was both natural and legitimate ; in all parts of the world, stocks in hand had almost reached exhaustion point, owing to the prolonged limitation of supply. When, therefore, millowners were enabled, by toe heavy fall in the price of raw cotton, to increase output with good prospect of substantial profit, foreign importers from Manchester hastened to replenish their stocks at the lower rates. But another effect was produced by this sudden augmentation of the external demand. It stimulated the building of new factories to an unprecedented extent; a correspondent of the "Morning Poet" estimates that in another six months, Lancashire will have in operation between three and four million spindles and forty-five thousand looms more than existed when the boom began. The future output will thus be increased by 10 percent., and should the foreign demand slacken, over-production will be sure to involve the inevitable penalty. But there is another menace, and, perhaps, of even more grave character. The American "corner" is scotched, not killed, and it only requires the stimulus of a short crop to ran up prices to record level, again paraysing the great Lancashire industry. There can never be any real safeguard against that standing danger until the British Cotton- Growing Association succeeds in its patriotic endeavour to render England independent of the New Orleans supply.

div.head: NILE VALLEY COMPANY
div.p: In another column we publish a report of the important meeting of the Nile Valley Company held on Monday week. At that meeting the reconstruction proposals were unanimously agreed to, the quotation hardening perceptibly as soon as the news reached the market. Among the economies which are to be effected are a reduction in the managing director's salary from £1,000 to £230 e year, with 2 1/2 percent commission on dividends, a reduction of £100 in the secretarial fees and office charges, a diminution in the fee of the consulting engineer by 250gs, and a decrease of £900 in directors' fees. These, it may be argued, are comparatively small retrenchments, but we understand that they may be taken as indicative of a policy of financial reform which is to be pursued as assiduously in Egypt as in London. The Nile Valley is a very fair mining risk, and it is by no means unlikely that shareholders who have gone into the reconstruction will see the whole of their money back in due time.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES
div.p: It was stated a few days ago that the Empain group of Brussels had decided to taka in hand the reconstruction of this unfortunate Egyptian sugar concern. On enquiries made in Paris circles in close touch with the Empain group, I am (a correspondent of a financial contemporary says) able to state that the news is not likely to be true ; so far, not the least confirmation exists. M. Empain's visit t> Cairo, where the affairs of the newly promoted Heliopolis Tramway Company required hi presence, baa no doubt given rise to the rumour. On the other hard, it is more than ever certain (adds the correspondent) that Sir Ernest Cassel and his friends are actively engaged in the reconstruction scheme.

div.head: Quarantine.
div.p: Quarantine restrictions as against plague are new applied to arrivals from Bassein in Egyptian ports.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said, will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alex­andria, at 4.45 p.m. to-day.

A Khedivial decree has been issued confirm­ing the election of twenty-tour members of the Coptic National Council at Cairo.

The official inauguration of the artesian wells at Rodel Farag will take place on March 15H.H the Khedive will probably be present at the ceremony.

M. Phil. D Philippides has contributed £1 and M. and Mme D. Theodorakis a similar amount to the Radolph Home, in memory of the late Hans von Tschndi.
Anglo-Egyptian Cigarette Company.

With the arrival of this company's n a-aging director, Mr. Max Prsedecki, the procuration given to Mr. Karl Lockemann daring his absence has ceased, and the signature of Mr. Przedecki will therefore alone be valid.
Concert.

A seiree musicale will be given in the hall of the Union Artisiquee Francaise on Friday next at 9 30 p.m. by Maestro F. Corbo, who comes from the Parma Conservatoire, assisted by Mile Capozzo, M. N. Naumides, and M. A. Roben.
The Doctors' Tariff.

There will be a meeting this evening at the headquarters of the Risorgimento Society to consider the report of the committee on the conference which it had with the Alexandria Doctors Society on the subject of the new medical tariff The meeting will begin at 7 o'clock this evening.
The Pilgrims' Return.

The Ministry of the Interior has received a telegram from the Quarantine Board representative at Tor, stating that the S S. Rahmanieh arrived there yesterday with 660 Egyptian pilgrims on board on their return from the Hedjaz. They are all in good health, except three.
A Free Dispensary.

A free dispensary for sick children was opened in Boulac at a new house in Sharia Maatba el Ahlia, near the Cotton Mills, yester­day. Mothers with sick babies may bring them from 8 a.m. till 10 a.m. daily for treatment gratuitously. This dispensary has been founded by Lady Cromer and is entirely supported by voluntary contributions.
Egypt Exploration Fund.

A new publication of the Fund is about to be issued comprising the fifteenth memoir of the Archaeological Survey of Egypt. It consists of part 111 of the work on the took tombs of El Arnarna. The author is Mr. N. do G. Davies and Mr. Seymour ce Ricci contributes an appendix on Greek Graffiti. The work is illustrated by 40 plates.
Dog Regulations.

As so many people seem to ignore the actual text of i he law concerning dogs, we may state that the order relating thereto runs as follows: - "All cogs running in the streets or public places in the town of Cairo or suburbs, must be muzzled or led on a leash. In either case they most wear a collar with a metal plate bearing name and address of the owner."
Football.

A capital game of football was witnessed at Gheziret Badrane last Friday, when the home earns and the R.E. met in their return match. The game was a very fast one and not until the final whistle blew did the tremendous excite­ment cease from reigning. In the first hail the exchanges were of an even character, and both custodians were called upon in torn. A notable feature of the match was the excellent exhibition given by the visitors' goalkeeper and many of his saves were really brilliant. When well into the second half, Simmonds scored a beautiful goal for the home team after a pretty piece of individual play. There was no further scoring and so the game conclude in a win for the Railway Institute by l-0 after a well contested game. Mr. Trotter was referee.

div.head: EGYPT'S PROSPERITY.IMPORTANT ARTICLE IN "TIMES."
div.p: An important communication appears in to­day's "Timer," wherein the present conditions of Egypt are reviewed. The writer, after starting with the contrary view, concludes that the continuous increase in land values in Egypt is a solid basis for the country's prosperity. One of the most investing points in the article is the reference to the great difficulty in the future, when Lord Cromer's guidance of Egypt comes to an end, for it will be a serious matter to find a successor. The Capitulations are, it is declared, a real danger to the country and their abolition is necessary. The writer gees on to state that the ranks and decorations con­ferred by the Khedivial Government should be for recognized merit only.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES.
div.p: There ii a very large demand for Deferred shares of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, which rose yesterday to 8 3/4, the ordinary being quoted 1 7/8.

div.head: THE DAIRA SANIEH CASE.
div.p: Yesterday the Second Civil Chamber of the Cairo Mixed Court gave judgment in the case brought by the villagers of Arment against the Societe Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh. The plaintiffs claim that their village has been sold over their heads. They were non-suited

div.head: KHARTOUM LANDS
div.p: The "Sudan Times" states that the 3nd»n Government has been approached by a powerful company which proposes to fill the agricultural lands in the western part of the town and raise them to the town level, the company to be granted half the land thus reclaimed. It is said that the Government is considering the proposal favourably. But, on the other hand, this seems doubtful, as it would be cheaper for the Government to do the work unaided. A few dredgers can serve the double purpose of clearing the river to facilitate navigation and filling the land in question.

div.head: CAIRO OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: Iris, not having recovered from the effects of her drenching, will not appear before Thursday, and last night Fedora took her place. The damages were inspected - we cannot say estimated—by Harari Pacha, M. Rocca Serra, Mr. Perry, and M. Pietri. Nothing is known of the damage done to the scenery as it was rolled up at the time of the accident and no one cares to enroll it till quite dry. Meantime it is rather curious, to say the least of it, that the Ministry of Public Works, on which the Opera House is dependent, has not' thought fit to make any communique to the Press on the subject.

div.head: JUDICIAL APPOINTMENTS
div.p: Ahmed Bey Abdeen, judge in the Native Court of Alexandria, has been appointed chief judge to the Court of Beni Souef, Upper Egypt; and Hussein Bey, a Parquet agent, judge of the 2nd class in the Native Court of Alexandria.
Many other transfers and appointments of judges have taken place, in accordance with a Khedivial edict recently issued.
Boutros Bey Youssef, judge in the Mixed Court of Mansourah, has refused to replace Mohamed Bey Naggari, judge in the Alexandria Mixed Court of First Instance who has been transferred to Cairo.

div.p: The Moss liner Menes arrived at Liverpool esterday afternoon.

div.head: THE FRONTIER INICIDENT.
div.p: NEGOTIAITIONS ADVANCE.
ARRIVAL OF TURKISH OFFICIERS

We are informed that two Turkish officers of high rank belonging to the General Staff of the Ottoman Army, are on their way from i Constantinople to Egypt to discuss the frontier question with the Egyptian authorities. This marks a distinctly forward step in the course of the negotiations.

div.head: NEW PENSION LAW.
div.p: The Egyptian Government is at present obtaining expert actuarial advice on the subject of a new Pension Law from Messrs. Ryan and Wyatt, whose competence as high actuarial authorities has long been recognised in Eng­land. Messis. Ryan and Wyatt have already arrived at Cairo.

div.head: GREECE AND EGYPT
div.p: Mr. A. Naoum, first dragoman of the Hellenic Legation at Constantinople, was presented by M Rikakis on Monday to Mustapha Pacha Fehmy and the other members of the Cabinet, and paid calls yesterday on Lord Cromer and the other representatives of the Powers.

div.head: BRIDGING THE NILE.
div.p: The Cleveland Bridge a> d Engineering Com­pany, of Darlington, have been commissioned to take the borings across the Blue and the White Niles at Khartonm. with a view to ascertaining the nature of the strata and the most suitable types of railway bridges to construct at these points, where the Blue and the White Niles are each 1,200 feet wide. As the boring operations have to be concluded before July next, when the Niles will be in fall flood, a party of engi­neers are leaving for Khartoum on the 23rd inst The expedition will be accompanied by Mr. W. E. Pease, of Mowden, Darlington—a direct r of the Cleveland Bridge and Engineer­ing Company—and the boring operations will be under the charge of Mr. G. C. Imbault, of Darlington, the engineer who was in charge of the erection of the railway bridge over the river Zambesi at the Victoria Falls, which was only recently completed by the Cleveland Bridge and Engineering Company.

div.head: THE WALL OF THE TIGRANES
div.p: The action brought by Mr. Georgacopoulo, owner of the New Khedivial Hotel at Cairo, against the heirs of the late Tigrane Pacha, came on for hearing before the Cairo Mixed Coart yesterday. The plaintiff was represented by Maitre Schaar and Maitre Privat appeared for the defendants. The case is based on the wail built by the Tigranes, the only purpose of which, plaintiff alleges, is to cut off the air and light from his property. Counsel f r the latter showed that the wall was an absolutely ageless construction and had only been built to fulfil a vow formulated by the late Tigrane Pacha, and that the Court should order its demolition in accordancee with the legal maxim ''Malitiis hominum non eat indulgendum."
Judgment will be delivered in a week.

div.head: TRADE IN GUM ARABIC

div.head: ABBASSIEH OASIS
div.p: THE PRINCE OF LAND
WHAT THE COMPANY IS DOING.

A slight decrease in the value of land at Zeitoun has been noticed since the formation of the Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oasis Company. Speculators have been soared at the immense quantity of land which this company could place on sale at a low price

We do not think, however, that these appre­hensions are justifiable. In the first place, the company has no interest in selling its lands before the construction of' the electric railways, the tran ways, the roads, etc. Second­ly. as the real cost price of these lands is rather high, it is impossible for them to sell them at a low price. In this connection it is to be noted that, albeit the price paid to the Government for the land is very small, the sum necessary to give it a market value will be enormous. There is a costly railway to be built, tramways to be laid, a supply of water and electricity to be furnished, roads to he made, pavements, public parks, etc,etc. Briefly, after spending £*00.000, as the area of the laud which is to be sold in lots amounts to two million square metres, the "immediate" price of the lands for sale comes to 40 piastres a square metre. We have said the "immediate" price because the price must be increased every year and this for some time, through losses on the working of the railway, the tram­ways, the distribution of water and electricity. It is certain that the rentals for the villas and hotels on the construction of which the company is to spend from £400 000 to £500,000 will hardly suffice to make up for these initial losses of exploitation. To all this must be added interest on £1.200,000 to £1.800.000, which, at 5 per cent., represents an annual anm 60000 to 65000

All this enumeration of charges brings ns to the conclusion that if the "immediate" cost price is 40 piastres per square metre, this price mast be increased by 8 to 3^ piastres a year to keep pace with the interest on the money expended

With the view of granting certain advant­ages to those persons who are the first to come and build on the Oasis, it is possible, and even probable, that the company will sell a hun­dred lots of 1,000 to 2,000 square metres, at the maximum, at lower than cost price, on condition only that houses are construct­ed the eon within a year ; bat, as we said above, it is not these hundred lots of land to be sold cheap which is likely to have an influence on the value of land at Zeitoun or Matarieh.

div.head: HEDJAZ RAILWAY
div.p: A Syrian trader who has recently arrived in Egypt from Palestine informed one of our representatives yesterday that a considerable movement of troops, mainly infantry of the Nisam (first line) from Ma'an to Qala'st Medawara, had recently taken place. Five thousand men are now engaged on railway work near Medawara, where water abounds and where there is a certain amount of cultivation. These troops were all armed with the Martini.

Preliminary surveys of the Ma'an-Akaba route having proved that a line between these points would be very costly and that the want of water would be a serious impediment to construction, it was finally decided to consider the question of a line between Qala'at Medawara over the Hisma plateau. A pre­liminary survey of the line by a party com j posed of an Italian, two Turkish engineers, and a Pole showed that no great natural difficulties existed, and in September last three Germans, who were said to have come from Akaba, arrived at Damascus from Me dawara. having made a farther survey of the route. The construction of embankment between Medawara and Akaba has already commenced, and a considerable amount of material for the construction of bridges has been sent down.

Medawara, which lies about 120 kilometres S.S.E. of Ma'an, is an excellent base for the construction of a branch line. It is well sup plied with water, cultivation flourishes, and provisions can be obtained on the spot The rolling stock of the line will shortly be largely increased, 10 large Kraus engines (all made in Germany) and about 150 carriage* and trucks having been ordered. The first lot of engines will arrive very shortly, at d sir greatly needed as the rolling stock on the main line from Damascus to Medawara has suffered greatly from inexperienced engineers, and in most cases requires a thorough repair and overhaul. The Bedouins have given heauthorities very little trouble lately having been timorised into peaceful ways by the Turk and Circassian mounted guards and no opposition is to be apprehended on the line between Akaba and Medawara.

div.head: THE CAIRO SALON
div.p: CORRESPONDENT'S CRITICISM
DEARTH OF LOCAL CANVASES
A Cairo correspondent writes to ns as
follows :—

Those who visit the "Cercle Artistique" expecting to find, as in previous years, a collec­tion of charming views of Egypt and the East, by artists all more or less connected with the country, are likely to experience some disappointment. The present exhibition, which figures under the name of "L'Exposition des Beanx Arts," is composed almost entirely of a series of pictures which, after having been displayed in the studios and galleries of Paris, have journeyed to Egypt in search of public favour. Amongst them are several of undoubt­ed merit, and these will be found well worthy of a visit. It is equally true, however, that the collection includes a great many which do not rise beyond the level of mediocrity.

But apart from the questions of merit or demerit, what strikes the Cairene is the sweeping change made in the nature of the exhibition by the elimination from it of what constituted the principal charm of previous shows, namely, their essentially local character. It may well be doubted whether this new departure will ' render the exhibition more attractive either 1 to residents or strangers. The former class are naturally more interested in representations of Egyptian life and scenery, than in views of foreign countries, whilst the latter class will 1 hardly be attracted by works which they have already had opportunities of seeing in Europe, and which include such well worn subjects as l the Arc de Triomphe, Notre Dame, and the Parisian boulevards.

It is true that in one room of the building some of what may be called local pictures are displayed. But they are insignificant in number, end the room is so badly lighted that it is difficult to form an opinion as to their merits. So little have they been considered by the promoters of the exhibition that by f*r the greater n amber have not been even mentioned in the catalogue. Here also one looks in vain for the names of Talbot Kelly, John Varley, alfred East. Sir John Rogers, Binder Scarselli, and others, whose works formed such an attractive feature in previous exhibitions, and whose absence from the present one everyone interested in art in Egypt must deplore.

div.head: SAVOY CONCERT
div.p: Fraulein Nelly Schlar-Brodmann and Herr Buff Gressen gave a very interesting concert on Sunday night at the Savoy Hotel, which was well attended and obviously more than satisfied the audience. The acoustics of the concert- room militated against the complete success of either artist; both would have been heard to better advantage in an opera-house, espe­cially Herr Buff Gressen, whose powerful and very pure tenor organ did not quite accom­modate itself to the conditions. None the less he sang admirably, his rendering of the frail romance "In fernem Lande," from Partial, and of Lohengrin's "Alschied," the latter given as an encore, being extremely thorough and artistic, and after a course if Mediterranean misreadings of Wagner it was delightful to hear a German do full justice to music that can never perhaps be fully appreciated south of the Alps and the Loire. Fraulein Brodmann sang well throughout but for one noticeable mistake over a drop 'hat should have been clean but she slurred over three notes. She was at her best in the three Schumann songs, and gave a good rendering of Tosti's Ninon, but her voice suffered from the room. In a concert- ball or opera-house it would have been far more attractive, but one can hardly criticise a performer who has not had time to learn the acoustics of the Savoy ball-room.

div.head: SHEPHEARD'S SMALL DANCE
div.p: There was a numerous assembly on Monday night at Shepheard's, when one of the usual small dances was in progress, and though there was perhaps a smaller proportion of residents and those living in other hotels present than in the commencement of the season, there was no diminution in the numbers of those who joined in the dance or amused themselves in less active fashion in the comfortable hall- passage. Nearly every one in the hotel must have been present, with the exception of the tired and travel-stained wayfarers from the further East, who filed through the brightly dressed crowd on their way to their rooms during the evening. The parquet floor if the Egyptian hall was in perfect condition and attracted several who thought their dancing days were over, and there were many who refused to tear themselves away from the festive scene till tin orchestra had resolutely refused to play a last encore. The programmes of the popular belles are now so crowded that their admirers have to console themselves with what are called "out dances," and the extra waltzes given as encores are also eagerly sought after. It is to be feared that the hum-drum ances of England with their scarcity of men will no long-r he welcomed by those who n>n ^e danger of having their heads turned by ' e glories of the Cairo season.

div.head: HEIR TO TURKISH THRONE
div.p: It is currently stated in Constantinople that Mohamed Rechad Effendi, her to the throne under the Ottoman law of succession, has bad serious apoplectic seizure. The news create o surprise because though not exactly f advanced years Rechad is in his 62nd year should he die his claims would descend to Yusuf Izzecin Effendi, who is 48 years of age. He is a Field Marshal of the Turkish Army and commands the Imperial guard.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Grand Duke Joseph of Austria is expect­ed to arrive at Alexandria on Monday next by the North German Lloyd steamer. The Khedive has placed a special train at his disposal.
H. E. the Governor of Alexandria left yester­day for Cairo.
Our Ghirgeh Correspondent telegraphs that Sir Horace Pinching arrived there to day.

Major P. W. Hardy, R.AM.C., Sanitary Officer in Egypt, came down to Alexandria from Cairo to-day on inspection duty. He leaves for Crete on the transport Dunera on the 24th inst, and returns by the same vessel.
Captain R L Mean, A.8.C., has come to Alexandria to await embarkation for England on the transport Dunera on the 1st proxo.

Sir Savile Brinton Crossley and Lady Crossley are staying at the Ghezireh Palace Hotel. Sir Savile Crossley represented Halifax in the House of Commons daring the last Parliament and on the formation of Mr. Balfour's late Ministry in 1902 he was appointed Postmaster General and in the same year Privy Councillor. He succeeded his father, the first Baronet, in 1872. He served in the South African war as captain of the Imperial Yeomanry, when he received the medal with four deeps and was promoted to the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel, and he is Major and Hon. Lieut-Col of the Prince of Wales' Own Norfolk Artillery Lady Crossley was the Hon. Phyllis de Bathe, daughter of Sir Henry de Bathe, who dis­tinguished himself in the Crimean War.

div.head:
CHINESE LABOUR
CABINET DISSENSIONS
HEAVY DEPRECIATION OF SHARES

div.p: It is believed that considerable differences exist in the Cabinet concerning the Transvaal Constitution and the Chinese labour questions. (Reuter)

The heavy fall continues in Kaffirs on the Government's policy. Difficulties are apprehend ed for the Thursday settlement. Since the 22nd of January, 40 leading shares have depre­ciated to the extent of £18,000,000. (Reuter)

div.head:
GOVERNMENT POLICY
STATEMENT BY THE PREMIER

div.p: House or Commons.—Sir H. Campbell-Ban­nerman said that so far as he knew the Algeciras Conference was proceeding slowly but satisfactorily. We were giving France our utmost diplomatic support without the slightest prejudice to our amity with other Powers. He emphatically declared that the understanding with France was as strongly entrenched as ever. He defended the giving immediately of a responsible Government to the Transvaal. The Government's great aim in flaming a constitu­tion would be to avoid any appearance of unfairness.
He reiterated the accusation that the condi­tion of Chinese labour was servile and cruel. No Chinaman desirous of returning home would be kept back against his will. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE ADRESS
ADOPTED BY THE LORDS

div.p: The Lords adopted the Address. Lord Crew denied that the election was won by misrepre­sentations with regard to the importation of Chinese labour. (Reuter)
The City Liberals have selected Mr. Gibson Bowles to oppose Mr. Balfour in the City. (R.)

div.head:
EXPEDITION TO SOKATO
A NEW MAHDI

div.p: An expedition is going to Sokato, where fanatics have killed a company of mounted , troops, constituting practically half the garri­son, including 5 white officers, and captured a « Maxim gun. It is Relieved that they ware sur­prised by the followers of a new Mahdi who were well armed. The affair was utterly unexpected. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE GARTHER MISSION
AN UNPARALLED HONOUR

div.p: The Mikado did Prince Arthur of Connaught unparalleled honour in meeting his Royal Highness at the station amid enthusiastic ovations on the part of the populace (Reuter)
Japan has called the attention of China to the advisability of checking any anti-foreign agitation. (Reuter)
The Reichstag has passed the commercial treaty with Abyssinia. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE HUNGARIAN DIET
SURROUNDED BY TROOPS

div.p: The Diet to-day was surrounded by troops. The Royal Commissioner sent in a rescript dis­solving the House and reserving the question of summoning another Diet. The Lower House unanimously returned the rescript unopened and adjourned. The Commissioner's delegate subsequently read the rescript to an empty house. Troops cleared out the House and the officials sealed the doors. (Reuter)
The Legislative elections will take place on April 89. (Havas)
The opinion prevails here that the failure of the Conference of Algeciras is inevitable, the French and German views on the crucial ques­tion of the police being irreconcilable. (Reuter)
The newspapers are unanimous in stating that it is impossible to make any farther con­cessions in connection with Morocco. (Havas)
The Turki again bombarded the factory of Marchica and destroyed several sheds. (R.)

M. Fallieres, in a message to the Chambers, emphasised the stability of the present regime and appealed for the co operation of all Repub­licans. He said that it was the sacred duty of the army to defend their country and the flag without menacing anybody. (Reuter)
M. Fallieres's message appeals for the co­operation of all Republicans and extols the defence of the country. (Havas)

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible (or the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit — within certain necessary limits—free discussion

div.head: THE RENUNCIATION OF CHITTY BEY
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

Dear Sir,—The principle so clearly laid down by the Director-General of Customs in his renunciation of the offer of the National Bank's Governorship involves a question of great public interest, which was only partially dealt with in year interesting article in yesterday's issue of the "Gazette." The selection of untried and untrained men for posts of great import­ance and responsibility cannot he too strongly deprecated. To require or even to permit a school teacher, for example, to discharge the functions of a lawyer, a soldier those of a financier, or a tax-collector those of a banker, exhibits a perversity which it is hard to ex­plain and which can under no conceivable circumstances he justified. When, in these conditions, failure takes place, and incompe­tence becomes markedly manifest, it is not the individual who is so much to blame as the system, or rather want of system, which not alone tolerates but fosters the selection of unqualified individuals.

It was recently remarked by Sir Oliver Lodge in addressing the Social and Political Education League that the art of government could not continue to be the one department of activity to which no training was supposed to be necessary. We trained engineers, we were beginning to train teachers, and some day poli­ticians must he trained too ! These observa­tions apply with equal if not greater force to all branches of the public service, though un­happily in Egypt the lesson that they inculcate is rarely taken to heart. That heads of great public departments too often occupy those very important positions without having undergone any preparation whatever to qualify themselves fur these high offices, is too well known to need for these high offices, is too well known to need instancing. The course of training available through the various stages of promotion is as a rule altogether avoided. This is the great blot which constitutes the inherent weakness cha­racteristic generally of the entire organisation of the public service in Egypt. Unhappily it is not the only defect. It appears to be an almost invariable custom that as soon as the head of any department has been long enough in one position to have gained some slight practical knowledge of the office he is appointed to administer he—notwithstanding that his abi­lity in administering his office may be consi­dered "quite phenomenal"—is shifted else­where and has consequently to begin an education for his new duties only to be again removed elsewhere before that education can be said to have been completed. Thus it seems to be assumed that as soon as a man has entered official life he is equal to the performance of duties of a most complex and comprehensive character. Special training and qualification, i even for the very highest offices of State, are absolutely ignored and rarely are such favour­ed individuals permitted to remain long enough in any one department to admit of their gaining more than a superficial knowledge of the working of their office. It cannot be conducive to the welfare of this country that high offi­cials in the public departments should be men amateurs, as under the present system many of them are, and very little more 5 and that through their rapid transfer from one department to another, the technical experience gained in their former capacity can stand them in but little good stead under the changed conditions of their new and entirely different duties.

Not the least of the evils attendant upon the distribution of high office amongst those whose length of service or previous experience gives them no legitimate claim, is that their promotion necessarily act) as a discouragement to those who have borne the beat and burden of the day in their respective offices, and who are therefore folly qualified to hold the posi­tions from which they are thus debarred by these more fortunate but less qualified favourite. To have acquired practical know- of the day in their respective others, and who are therefore folly qualified to hold the positions from which they are thus debarred by these more fortunate bat less qualified favourites. To have acquired practical knowledge and experience of the department in which a public official shall be placed in charge would appear to be in the majority of instances the last thing necessary, if not a distinct disqualification, whilst moreover a civil servant receives but little or no encouragement to take any special interest in the performance of his duties, since after having served, per­haps, for one half of his total service in one branch, he finds himself suddenly transferred to another branch, wherein the technicalities of his previous experience will prove to be absolutely or relatively—useless. It may, of course, and doubtlessly would be, claimeds that in each case of promotion the beet roan, in the opinion of those responsible, is invariably selected. Bat it is clear that the od6 who is considered the best for any appointment is not necessarily the one most qualified by previous training and experience for the post. By what special line of reasoning and argument a man can be considered fully competent to control a responsible and per­haps a large department whose previous services have been utilised in a different branch of the service it is impressible to divine save upon the principle that there is one supreme and universal intellect which ermpr. h- nds, orders, gui les, and governs the administrative machinery in its t tality, and that therefore all other brains are at a discount or of little account whatsoever. All that has been alleged above points, 1 submit, to the necessity for a thorough examination into I ha whole system of administration and a reorganisa­tion of present methods of selection and pro­ne otion in the true interests of tha country and of the public service generally, whereby the tendency of plaoing the round man in the square hole may be in great measure arrested even if it cannot be entirely repressed. —Truly yours, Common Sense.

div.head: CEREAL IMPORTS
div.p: The main contributor to last year's total expansion of imports was the cereal class which was op by I. E. 786,942, a substantialincrease over 1904. The reason for the additional imports lies in the fact that the native cultivator, instead of growing his own grain, etc, is now putting more of his Ian*4 under cotton, with the result that he is com­pelled to boy cereals for his own consumption. If such-a step resulted in the "fellah" obtaining a larger crop of cotton without impairing the fertility of the land, and assuming he were able to sell the same at something approaching current prices, the change would obviously he a good one for the country in general, since the margin between the value of the cotton and that of the cereals would he profit. Unfor­tunately, we are afraid such conditions are not altogether being experienced at the present time, the native having, apparently, to sow a larger area in order to, approximately, secure the same crop. It is, of course, tune that the present high prices of cotton somewhat com­pensate for the inferior crop, hot there still remains the serious question of land impoverishment. We think, therefore, that we are justifi­ed in saying that the additional shipments of grain do not altogether indicate increased prosperity on the part of Egypt.

div.head: MAPLE AND CO'S REPORT
div.p: The directors of Maple and Company are to be congratulated on the excellent results shown by the company for the past year. Although trade generally has not been particu­larly active, the report just issued shows a net profit of £122,000, an increase of £9,7' 0 on the figures for the previous twelve months. A further satisfactory features that the direc­tors have adhered to a conservative policy. Thus of the increase in profits barely half is awarded 69 extra dividend to make up the 15 awarded &s extra dividend to nuke up the 1* percent. recommened, while the remainder is placed to reserve, making ta^t fund £321,000, or nearly 20 per cent, of the issued capita1.

div.head: RESULT OF DRINKING TOO LITTLE
div.p: Dr. Willoughby lecturing at the Institute of Hygiene, made the interesting statement that "for every person who drinks too much alcohol there are ten who drink too little water, and gaffer in consequence from headache, languor, and many other ills."

div.head: THE WORLD'S LARGEST LINER
div.p: Messrs. Harlard and Wolff announce that the White Star liner Adriatio, which they are building. will be the largest vessel in the world. She will have a displacement of 25,000 tone, will be 710$ ft. long, 75 ft. broad, and 50 ft. deep.

div.head: MIXED UP
div.p: A bridegroom at St. John's, Kilburn, was asked by the vioar the onstomary question, 'Wilt thou have this woman to be thy wedded wife1)" and he replied in the words of the Charoh catechism, "I renounoe them all."

div.head: QUEEN VICTORIA'S COURTSHIP
div.p: The wooing of the King of Spain recalls the courtship of Queen Victoria, who had to take the first step towards her marriage with Prince Albert herself. Lady Violet Greville says, in the ' Chronicle," that the young Sovereign summoned the Prince to hor bou­doir, where he 'found her alone. After some desultory talk due to her shyness, she sudden­ly said : ' Could you forsake your country for me ?" The Prince answered by clasping her in his arms. In such simple fashion did a young Sovereign woo and win the husband of her choice.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: TRIBUNAL MIXTE DU CAIRE
arena contre Egyptian Delta Light Railways Company Limited
Qn«lqnfi8 jngements assez intéressants, en matière ' d'accident;'ontrété rendos-îtmdi tratin oar la première chambre civile présidée par M. Prnnières.

Le premier de ces jugements est relatif à Tins* tance introduite par la dame Venva Lonis Arena, représentée par Mtre Morpnrgo. à l'en contre de la Delta Light Railway Co, laquelle réclamait une indemnité de L!E. 1000 à la dite société, rendant responsable cette dernièrede la mort de son mari, le Sieur Arena, écrasé le 20 février 1905 par un ttfein é£ Vendant de la gare de Zayet el Zenab à la gare de Bab-el-lonk.

Le Tribunal, après quelques considérants, se basant sur le règlement en vigueur aux che­mins de fer, qui interdit le passage et l'accès dès voies au public, rejette la dehoande de la Veuve Arena et la condamne aux frais.

div.head: CAPITAL CONTRE ADMINISTRATION DES CHEMINS DE FER DE' L ETAT
div.p: Le denx'ème jugement, est relatif à une in­demnité de L.E >5,000 réclamée à l'adminis­tration des chemins de fer par M. Egisto Capi- tani, entrepreneur italien pour les maladies ou infirmités graves que lui auraient causés l'acci­dent de obemin de fer survenu le 14 août 1902 au train express allant vers la Haute-Egypte qui dérailla entre les stations d'Abou-Ticht et Perchât par Boite de la rencontre subite d'ane tnfflesse qui se j*ta brarquement snr la voie

Le tribunal, se basant sur le certificat du Dr Tonin, médecin légiste du consulat d'Italie, et sur certains témoignages, attestant que M. Oapitani est un alcoolique, qu'il est de ce chef atteint d'accès furieux (frenent alcoolica) et qu'il y a tout lieu de 1 interner ; avant que de juger au fond ordonne un, complément d'en­quête pour laquelle il désigne le Dr Brossard.

div.head: CRITELLI CONTRE THE TELEPHONE COMPANY OF EGYPT LIMITED
div.p: Le troisièmejn^ement en matière d'accident, est relatif à on acoidént de travail dont a été victime M. Gregorio Crûelli, ouvrier éleotrioien au service de la compagnie des téléphones du Caire, ponr lequel il assigne le directeur de la dite compagnie en paiement d'une indemnité de 1,500 L.E.

Le 10 mai 19^5, le demandeur qui était chargé de réparer des fils téléphoniques sur la ligne de Rod el Farag, fut précipité à terre, par la chnte du poteau sur lequel il était mon­té pour accomplir son travail.
Dans cette chute M. Gregorio Gritelli fut victime de plusieurs blessures une fracture du bras droit, une autre de la jambe gauche et de fortes contusions à l'épine dorsale.

Le Tribunal, avant qoe de statuer sur le fond, ordonne la nomination d'un médecin comme expert, à l'effet d'examiner le demandeur et dire s'il se trouve dans l'impossibilité de tra­vailler à la suite de l'accident dont il a été viotime.
M. le Docteur Brossard a été nommé expert en la dite matière.

div.head: L'AFFAIRE DES FRERES
div.p: Grande sfflùence hier au Tribunal mixte de Ire instance du Caire où se plaidait devant la 2me Chambre civile présidée parM. Herzbruch le procès en dommages-intérêts intenté pax MM. Mszaltob et Mansour aux Frères des Ecoles chrétiennes au sujet des incidents autour desquels on a mené grand bruit en juillet 1904.

L'audience commence à 9 heures 30. Me. Morpurgo, au nom des demandeurs.expose que ceux-ci réclament 100,000 livres de dommages pour le préjudice qui leur a été causé par les faits et gestes du Frère Alexis. Me. Morpurgo appuie la demande sur "la volonté de nuire" des défendeurs, sur le jugement rendu parle Tribunal oonsulaire d'Italie et sur les frais de médecins ;et autres encourus par les parents des enfants.
A IA ViAnvna 1 KMa Wi/loi
Tribunal consulaire d'Italie et sar les frais de médecins . et autres encourus par les parents des enfants.

A 10 heures 15 Me Widal présente pendant une heure la défense des Frères. Me. Wtdal dit qu'il s'agit en l'espèce de oa qu'on appelle en matière théâtrale une "reprise" "L'agitation faite autour de ce procès s'est calmée les Frère* sont sortis glorieux de la rude épreuve et après avoir reo nquis la confiance de tons ont va llamment démontré l'inanité de l'abomi­nable accusation dont ils ont éréTobjet. Aussi, après avoir porté leur affaire devant le Tri bunal mixte, ils ee sont désisté de leur action principale. Mais nos adversaires n'ont pas voulu abandonner l'arme forgée contre nous et ils viennent réclamer une enquête devant la justice mixte."

Me Widal démontre ensuite que l'enquôte est inutile après que l'autorité 'compétente a statué sur cette affaire. L'avocat des Frères étaille l'enquête du juge d'instruction au •onsulat de France, donne lecture des déposi­ons faites an cours de cette enquête fait res­sortir que tous les témoignages des personne*) citées par les parents des enfants sont défavo­rables à l'accusation. Me Widal' rélève encore que d'après les déclarations de Victor Maealtob elni-oi s'était absenté 6 jours, du 16 au 22 j in, période au cours de laquelle les faits se iraient produits et Félix Mansour a été absent 3 jour* dans le même mois. ^

L'honorable défenseur discute ensuite le cré­dit qu'il faut accorder auxfv déclarations des nfanta ; il constate que le* faits remontent à 2 -ns, pois signale dans quelles conditions, en quelques heures seulement, l'affaire a été églée par le Tribunal consulaire d'Italie.

Me Widal conc'ut en disant qne le tri­bunal mixte a le choix entre deux jugements tout à fait différents par la compétence juridique et par les conditions dans lesquelles ils ont été rendus. L'avocat des Frères termine par un point juridique,1 celui considérant les Frères comme une Maison d'Eduoation. Il cite deux jugements à l'appui de sa thèse, soit la valeur des déclarations d'un enfant en matière d'at­tentat à la pndeur.
Apiè* une petite répl'qne de Me Morporgo, le Tribunal dit que le jugement sera rendu à hoitsi ie, mais sur l'insistince de l'avocat des demandeurs, le prononcé a été remis à quin­zaine.

Nouvelle baisse sur les cotons en Amérique. Le dit-pnnible a perdu hier 15 points à 11.10, le Mai 13 points et l'Octobre 5.
Les arrivages ont été de 15,000 balles contre 15,000.
Le marché de Liverpool est plus ou moins stationnaire.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6.
